div.p:
As you were so kind as to wish
to hear from us after our return home I am
sure it will give you pleasure to know
that my poor Lucy is altogether much
better and stronger than she has appeared
since she quitted the healthy seaside
She looked so ill in Dublin and appeared
so feeble during our stay in the County of Meath
that I was rather apprehensive that another
course of Calomel would be necessary. But thank
God she has become quite stout and absolutely
has a tinge of colour color in her cheeks without
having recourse to any medicine whatever
She has walked out every day and even
worked a little in her garden with the Pakenhams
assistance before after his hours of Latin & Euclid begins
This has some hopes that you will remember
her as a poor petitioner for some of the sorts
of plants that may be spared from the depouilles
of the Observatory Garden - and Honora too had

had an old promise of double yellow Tulips
& Double Anemones which she now hopes
you will have the goodness to recollect -
Any roots or plants left at Mrs Wallis's
will reach us quite safely - and you must
know how much their having been yours
will add to their intrinsic value -

I want to hear more of you - to know
what you are all about - if you have begun
the dreadful work of packing yet? - What a
thing the sending off all those books will be!
You may freight a ship with books and
furniture. I hope to hear that Mrs
Mat
has Mathas
got safely through her painful hearing
and that a future Bishop has rewarded
her, & that he is as promising & lovely as his
little precursors.

The appointing a New Observer will I sup-
-pose suppose take place very soon and I am very very
anxious to hear that some one may be named
who is likely to follow up the Course laid down
for himself by your dear Bishop - who will do
honour to the place he has made so honorable

and do credit to this country where so few
people imagine anything good or wise
can be found - Above all I hope more
earnestly than would be right to expect
that no job may be even suspected in the
appointment. The Bishop looks so like
a Bishop - so handsome & so benevolent &
so good that it would have been a sad pity
had he not fulfilled the destiny that
awaited him - long may he adorn

the lawn sleeves
& mitre and set an

example to the other lords of the Church!
I wish I could form any reasonable ground
of hope that I could see you both here
Is not his presence necessary to give up his little
Roscommon parish? This you know wd
just be the road.

William will I think continue to see you
on his way to England - and to him I leave
the describing how well we found Lovell
& how well Honora & Fanny are - & how happy Harriet appears to be
I have informed Mrs Black that her lodger old Mary
is to return to you at Christmas or a

to you - and she in return wishes much that
some one else - as quoit as he & paid for, by as good
pay as you could be sent to her - She says he
wants 2 pairs of Stockings - any - His quarterly
boarding ends the 15th - of November - Shall he
begin another?
div.closer:
Adieu my dear Mrs Brinkley my sincere
love to the dear good Bishop and my dear Mrs
R. Graves - not forgetting Mr Matthew B. &
Believe me always yours truly
Affectionate F. Edgeworth
Very comfortable accounts of our dear Francis from Cambridge
